Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Synthesis and Reactivity of Coordinatively Unsaturated Zwitterionic Half-Sandwich Group VIII Metal Complexes
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research award in the Chemical Synthesis (SYN) program in the Division of Chemistry at NSF supports work by Professor Paul J. Fischer at Macalester College to synthesize and probe the reactivity of neutral half-sandwich organometallic complexes that feature a formal +1 charge on a group VIII metal (M = Fe, Ru, Os) and a formal -1 charge on a B atom within the ligand backbone. Related positively charged group VIII complexes are intermediates in metal-catalyzed organic transformations; this project probes how reactivity can be tuned by employing neutral complexes with an internal charge separation. The extent of electronic stabilization afforded by this M-B intramolecular charge separation will be probed via investigating syntheses of neutral complexes with unknown cationic analogues. This project trains Macalester College chemistry majors in chemical synthesis by teaching these students an array of critical skills for the synthesis and characterization of organic and inorganic compounds. Students will emerge from their research experiences with the laboratory skills and maturation as experimentalists to engage all aspects of graduate level synthetic research projects.

The impact of an intramolecular charge separation on organometallic complex reactivity informs catalyst design strategies; complexes synthesized via this study will be excellent candidates for cross-coupling, atom transfer radical addition, and atom transfer radical cyclization reactions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Award enabled eight Macalester College (St. Paul, MN) undergraduates to engage intensive research training in "organometallic synthesis" under the tutelage of the PI. These students were challenged to master the laboratory techniques and background knowledge to prepare and study new molecules that contain bonds between metals and carbon atoms. The most significant broader impact leveraged by this Award is equipping students with the skills necessary to transition efficiently to productive careers at top-flight graduate chemistry programs and to careers as chemists in academia and industry. The preparation and design of organometallic compounds continues to be a core aspect of solving global problems associated with energy challenges, the production of materials for use in society (for example polymers and pharmaceuticals) and “small molecule activation” (the science of generating high value compounds using small, inexpensive molecules as starting materials).

Of the aforementioned eight students, four have graduated to date. Three of these have matriculated in organometallic Ph.D. programs (MIT, Columbia University and Emory University). These three students are building on the sturdy foundation afforded by their NSF-funded research experiences as undergraduates. The fourth graduate is working in a Materials Science laboratory at 3M Corporation. Of the remaining four students, three are juniors considering graduate study in chemistry, and one is a senior who plans to matriculate in a top-flight graduate program to pursue organometallic chemistry in Fall 2015. The valuable and "hands-on" scientific and technical preparation that these students gained via these Macalester College research experiences would have been impossible to provide without NSF funding.

While my students enter my laboratory without any previous research experience in chemistry, my objective as a PI is to lead these students through the entire process of "chemical scholarship", from formulating hypotheses, designing experiments, interpreting experimental results, making conclusions and disseminating the work in peer-reviewed journals. My goal is to model for my students each vital aspect of being a successful chemist. All work funded by this Award has been published with corresponding student co-authorship in three peer reviewed articles in Organometallics (2, a leading journal of the American Chemical Society (ACS)) and in Dalton Transactions (1, a leading journal of the Royal Society of Chemistry (UK)).

Professional communication of results in oral and poster format is another vital aspect of research training. During the Award period, NSF funded trips by my students and I to three ACS National Meetings for five such presentations of our results. Two students and I will communicate our summer 2014 NSF-funded efforts via two accepted presentations at the Spring 2015 ACS National meeting. Participation and presentation at these meetings is valuable for my students; it affords them the opportunity to network with faculty at major research universities and learn more about prospective graduate programs.

The intellectual scope of this research falls under the category of "basic and fundamental" research. Our general goal is to design and prepare new organometallic molecules with specific structural features, and then study how the properties (or reactivity) of these molecules is impacted on the basis of these structural features. With this broad view in mind, the essence of each project funded by this Award is summarized below.

Project #1: We prepared 11 new molecules containing chromium, molybdenum and tungsten that are similar to previously reported molecules that are catalysts for "olefin epoxidation", a practical process via which an oxygen atom is "added" to a carbon-carbon double bond. The primary way our complexes are differ...
